Literature Review: The interplay between working memory and selective attention is pivotal for guiding flexible behavior, a concept that has garnered significant attention in cognitive neuroscience. This literature review delves into the 'inside-out' direction of selective attention, where working memory contents are modulated to influence behavior, contrasting with the 'outside-in' direction where sensory signals shape internal representations. The functional, flexible, and future-focused nature of inside-out selective attention is underscored, with a particular focus on visual working memory as a model system. The purpose, targets, sources, and mechanisms of selective attention within working memory are explored, revealing new insights into the core cognitive processes of attention and working memory. The integration of these processes offers a comprehensive understanding of how the mind serves behavior. The purpose of inside-out selective attention is to prioritize relevant mental contents for future actions, ensuring that behavior is guided by anticipated needs rather than immediate sensory inputs alone (Kiyonaga & Egner, 2013). This anticipatory function is crucial for goal-directed behavior, allowing individuals to prepare for and adapt to upcoming tasks and challenges. The targets of inside-out selective attention are the contents of working memory, which can include representations of sensory information, task goals, and action plans (Gazzaley & Nobre, 2012). By selectively attending to these contents, individuals can maintain and manipulate information relevant to their current objectives, facilitating efficient and effective behavior. The sources of inside-out selective attention are internal, originating from the individual's goals, expectations, and prior knowledge (Awh, Vogel, & Oh, 2006). These internal sources guide the allocation of attention within working memory, ensuring that the most relevant information is prioritized for guiding behavior. The mechanisms of inside-out selective attention involve the dynamic interplay between prefrontal and parietal brain regions, which are responsible for the control and maintenance of working memory contents (Curtis & D'Esposito, 2003). These mechanisms enable the flexible updating and prioritization of information in working memory, supporting adaptive behavior in response to changing environmental demands. The study of inside-out selective attention has revealed that attention and working memory are deeply intertwined, with each process influencing and being influenced by the other (Postle, 2006). This reciprocal relationship highlights the importance of considering both processes together for a holistic understanding of cognitive function. Furthermore, the integration of selective attention and working memory has practical implications for understanding and improving cognitive performance in various domains, including education, clinical psychology, and human-computer interaction (Unsworth & Engle, 2007). By elucidating the mechanisms by which the mind serves behavior, research on inside-out selective attention contributes to the development of strategies for enhancing cognitive efficiency and effectiveness. In conclusion, the burgeoning literature on inside-out selective attention underscores its critical role in guiding flexible, goal-directed behavior. By focusing on the purpose, targets, sources, and mechanisms of selective attention within working memory, researchers have gained new insights into the core cognitive processes of attention and working memory. The integration of these processes offers a rich and comprehensive understanding of how the mind serves behavior, paving the way for future research and practical applications in various fields.
